text: was a Japanese era name (年号, nengō, lit. year name) of the Northern Court during the Nanboku-chō period after Eiwa and before Eitoku. This period started in March 1379 and ended in February 1381.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Kōryaku" in Japan encyclopedia, p. 562. The pretender in Kyoto was Nussbaum, "Go-En'yū Tennō," p. 251; Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du japon, pp. 310-315. Go-En'yū's Southern Court rival in Yoshino during this time was .Nussbaum, "Chōkei Tennō," p. 120. ==Events of the Kōryaku era== * 1379 (Kōryaku 2): Shiba Yoshimasa became Kanrei.Ackroyd, Joyce. (1982) Lessons from History: The "Tokushi Yoron", p. 329. * 1380 (Kōryaku 3): Kusunoki Masanori rejoined Emperor Go-Kameyama. * 26 July 1380 (Kōryaku 2, 24th day of the 6th month): Former pretender Emperor Kōmyō died at age 60.Titsingh, p. 315. ==Southern Court nengō == * Tenju, 1375–1381 ==Related pages== * Muromachi period ==References== ==Other websites== * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Kōryaku 1st 2nd 3rd 1379 1380 1381 Preceded by: Eiwa Northern Court nengō: Kōryaku Succeeded by: Eitoku Category:Japanese eras Category:1370s establishments in Japan Category:1380s disestablishments in Japan
title: Kōryaku
